summary: This is a detailed analysis of a video tutorial by Timothy Adjokatse, a software developer and YouTuber, demonstrating how to convert a Facebook profile to a page.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen that transitions to a white background featuring a red play button surrounded by various emojis, including smiling faces, a winking face with a tongue out, and a face with heart eyes. The play button changes to a red 'SUBSCRIBE' button with a hand cursor clicking on it. The scene then shifts to a person's hands holding a smartphone on a speckled white table, navigating through the phone's interface. The person taps on the 'SUBSCRIBE' button, which changes to 'SUBSCRIBED' with a bell icon, indicating successful subscription. The video continues with the person scrolling through the phone's content, revealing a video thumbnail and a notification asking for permission to allow notifications. The person's name, Timothy Adjokatsé, and his title, Software Developer, appear on the screen, providing context about the individual. The video maintains a clean and minimalistic aesthetic throughout, focusing on the interaction with the smartphone and the subscription process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a suspenseful sound effect. Transitioning from this, a single male speaker greets the audience and asks them to subscribe to the channel and turn on the notification bell. The speaker then explains the purpose of the video which is a lesson.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person named Timothy Adjokatse, a software developer, interacting with a smartphone on a speckled white table. He navigates through various Facebook pages, including one titled "Eat Out," and scrolls through posts and comments. A 'Subscribe' button with a bell icon appears, suggesting a call to action for viewers. The video then transitions to a Facebook post by "React fellows," announcing a price increase for an event called "React Global," with a countdown of three days left. The post includes a graphic showing the price change from $249 to $299, emphasizing urgency with the text "PRICE INCREASE" and "3 DAYS LEFT!" The background remains consistent with a blue theme, and the atmosphere is informative, focusing on the content displayed on the smartphone screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker explaining how to convert a Facebook profile to a page. He explains how doing so can lead to monetization and payment from Facebook, which he will discuss further in a later video. He emphasizes that he will walk the listener through how to convert their profile into a page with "simple tricks". The male speaker mentions that "this is B strategies" and urges the listener to follow the steps.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a Facebook post announcing a price increase from $249 to $299, with a countdown of 3 days left, urging viewers to buy now to save on the React Global Summit. The post includes a 'Like,' 'Comment,' and 'Share' button, and a comment from a user named Doe-Quarshie Michael expressing sadness at Madina. The scene transitions to a laptop with a blank screen, followed by a smartphone displaying a Facebook profile named Timothy Adjokatse, with a notification of 3 updates. The user navigates to the 'Menu' section, revealing various shortcuts and options, including 'Settings & privacy,' 'Profile,' 'Account,' 'Personal information,' and 'Translation for posts.' The user selects 'Settings,' leading to a screen with options like 'Profile settings,' 'Account,' 'Personal information,' and 'Translation for posts.' The user then accesses 'Personal information,' where they can edit their name, contact info, and identity confirmation. The video concludes with the user editing their name, with a note advising against unusual capitalization or punctuation, and a 'Review Change' button. Throughout the video, a 'Subscribe' button appears intermittently, encouraging viewers to subscribe to the channel.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with a brief burst of electronic music, heavy on the bass, before transitioning to a tutorial. A male voice, calm and instructional, guides the listener through steps, stating, "Just click on your accounts," and "scroll down to settings and privacy." The tone suggests a how-to video. The tutorial continues with more verbal instructions related to a user interface.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a mobile phone displaying a Facebook profile editing page, where a user is attempting to change their name to "Adjokaste." The screen shows fields for first name, middle name, and surname, with a note advising against unusual capitalization, punctuation, or random words. The user clicks the "Review Change" button, leading to a loading screen. The next frame shows the Facebook Help Centre page titled "What names are allowed on Facebook?" with guidelines on acceptable names, including restrictions on symbols, characters, and titles. The user scrolls through the page, which lists various prohibited elements and mentions that an authentic name cannot be changed from a government ID list. The video then transitions to another loading screen, followed by a page titled "Changing Your Name," which explains Facebook's requirement for users to provide their everyday name and offers options to upload a government ID for verification. The user is prompted to enter a new first name and surname, with an optional middle name field. The video concludes with the user still on the "Changing Your Name" page, ready to submit their new name details.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker providing instructions about changing names on Facebook, with a somewhat instructional tone, cautioning listeners about limitations. He then guides listeners to click on "Learn More", which leads to the Facebook Help Center page and then further instructions, focusing on how to ultimately fill a form. The speaker emphasizes that the goal is not merely to change names but to convert a profile to a Facebook Page. The audio concludes with the speaker highlighting a short note stating timelines are for personal use.

events_list.video_caption: The video shows a computer screen displaying a Facebook account settings page where a user is attempting to change their name. The page has a blue background with white text and a form that includes fields for uploading documents, selecting a reason for the name change, and providing a contact email address. A red warning box at the bottom of the screen advises users that changing their name for personal reasons to represent a business or organization, or to represent oneself as a public figure, should be done by creating a Page instead of changing the account name. The user has not yet uploaded any documents, and the "Send" button is visible at the bottom of the form. The video remains static, focusing on the screen content without any visible actions or changes in the environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker, who suggests that if one is trying to change an account name to represent a business or public figure, they should create a page or convert their account. His tone is informative and helpful. He then mentions that he will show in another video how to create a standard Facebook page. He encourages the listener to subscribe and turn on notifications so they will be alerted when the video is released.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a Facebook account settings page, specifically the 'Name and contact info' section, where a user is prompted to upload a government ID or other forms to verify a new name. The page includes a 'Choose files' button for uploading documents, a 'Contact email address' field, and a warning message advising against changing the account name for personal use if the user represents a business or organization. The 'Send' button is highlighted in red. A 'Subscribe' button with a bell icon is visible on the right side of the screen. The scene transitions to a black screen with a white circle and a grid icon, indicating a loading or transition phase. The video then shifts to a Facebook Help Centre page, focusing on the 'Pages' section, which explains how to manage pages, invite people to like or share pages, assign roles, and add call-to-action buttons. The Help Centre page is displayed on a mobile device, with the time shown as 10:48. The video concludes with a continuation of the Help Centre page, emphasizing the 'Pages' section and its functionalities.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker who mentions converting an account to a page. He then elaborates that this account is a profile page and they want to convert it to just a 'page', instructing the listener to click on an option. The speaker transitions to describing how the click will take the listener to the Facebook Help Center and how the following display is what the user will see at the moment.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a mobile device screen displaying the Facebook Help Centre page, specifically focusing on the 'Pages' section. The interface is characterized by a blue header with the Facebook logo and a search icon, followed by a white background containing text and bullet points. The text explains that users can manage pages in the new Pages experience, follow pages for updates, and create pages with a Facebook account. It also provides instructions on inviting people to like or share pages and assigning roles. The time displayed on the device is 10:48, and the battery icon indicates a full charge. The video remains static, with no changes in the content or environment throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker with a somewhat instructional tone, discussing a feature that was available up to "somewhere 2020" but appears to have been removed or is potentially being updated by Facebook. He mentions that instead of taking users to specific steps, it directs them to a page.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user navigating through the Facebook Help Centre on a mobile device. Initially, the screen displays a section titled "Pages," explaining how users can manage pages and inviting them to learn more about the new Pages experience. The user scrolls down to reveal a list of help topics under the "Help Centre" section, including "Manage Page settings," "Customise a Page," "Publishing," "Messaging," "Insights," "Banning and moderation," and "Fix a problem." The user selects the "Fix a problem" option, leading to a feedback form asking, "Was this helpful?" with "Yes" and "No" options. The user chooses "Yes," and the form transitions to a section titled "What went wrong?" with options such as "The information is confusing," "The solution doesn't work," "I don't like the product or policy," and "Other." The user selects "The solution doesn't work" and proceeds to a text box labeled "Can you say more?" where they can provide additional feedback. The video concludes with the user typing a message in the text box and preparing to submit the feedback by clicking the "Submit" button. Throughout the video, the background remains a solid blue, and the interface elements are consistent with Facebook's design.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker is giving instructions or describing a process, noting that they will move down and ask if something was helpful, stating that it was not because they want to convert it into a Facebook page. He then instructs the listener to click "no" because it didn't help, and choose the option that "the solution does not work," leading to the option to contact Facebook. He mentions copying a Facebook profile and offering to show how to do it after completing this step. Finally, the speaker concludes that Facebook does not work. His tone is instructional and informative.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a smartphone screen displaying a Facebook Messenger feedback form. The form includes options such as "Messaging," "Insights," "Banning and moderation," and "Fix a problem," with a section titled "Can you say more?" that advises users that the form is for feedback only and will not receive a reply. The user is prompted to submit their feedback, with a "Submit" button visible. The scene transitions to the smartphone's home screen, showcasing various app icons like WhatsApp, Messenger, Facebook, Instagram, and others, with the date "Mon, 11 Apr" and a temperature of "32°C" displayed at the top. The video then shifts to a Facebook Messenger chat window, where a user has sent a link to a Facebook page and a message addressed to the Facebook team, expressing a desire to convert the page to English. The chat includes images labeled "fire conference.jpg" and a download icon indicating a file size of 221 KB. The video returns to the feedback form, where the user's finger is seen tapping the "Submit" button, indicating the submission of their feedback. The video concludes with the feedback form still visible on the screen, emphasizing the user's action of submitting their feedback.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with someone saying they've copied their profile already and have it with them, ready to paste, and then tell Facebook something didn't work for them to fix. The speaker believes Facebook is working on it, and encourages viewers to like the video so they can provide updates. The speaker sounds informative.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with a Facebook feedback form on a mobile device. The screen displays a blue background with a white feedback form at the top, containing a text box for input and a 'Submit' button. Below the form, there are sections titled 'Popular articles' and 'Resources for Page admins,' featuring links to articles and FAQs. The user types a message in the text box, which reads, "Hello Facebook team, I want to convert my Facebook profile to a Facebook page but this is not working. Please fix it." The message is then submitted, and the screen transitions to show the 'Popular articles' section with a 'Subscribe' button and a bell icon, indicating the user has subscribed to updates. The video concludes with the user's message displayed in the feedback form, ready for submission.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker is explaining how to update a video. He shares, "I'll just make updates to this video and show you how to go about it". He then describes copying and pasting content, including his Facebook profile and a short explanation for Facebook, with a neutral and informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a Facebook help page where a user is seeking assistance with converting their Facebook profile into a Facebook page. The page features a blue background with a white text box containing a message from the user, stating their issue and providing a link to their Facebook profile. Below the message, there is a "Submit" button. The page also includes sections titled "Popular articles" and "Resources for Page admins," offering links to articles on reporting fake accounts, adding stickers to a page's story, and interacting with pages. The user's message is highlighted in the "Fix a problem" section, emphasizing the need for assistance. The video captures the user's interaction with the help page, focusing on the text and layout of the page, with no visible people or objects other than the digital interface.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker addressing the Facebook team, expressing frustration about being unable to convert their profile to Facebook but states it is a minor issue that can be updated soon. He suggests a previous method that can be used still, explains that Facebook will give the user steps to fix the glitch, and advises to subscribe for updates. He decides not to submit his own profile for conversion and encourages the listener to try and subscribe for more details. The clip contains consistent clear speech throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a Facebook help page where a user is seeking assistance with a problem related to their Facebook profile. The user has typed a message explaining that they want to add their Facebook profile to a Facebook page but it is not working. The page includes a 'Submit' button and a section titled 'Popular articles' with resources for page admins. The scene transitions to a mobile phone screen displaying a loading icon, indicating that the user is waiting for a response or a page to load. The time on the phone reads 10:51. The next frame shows the same phone screen with the time now at 10:52, and a message from 'KALJAY' saying 'God when https://t.co/aQFD7E2Zz'. The Facebook app is then opened, showing the home screen with various icons and a 'SUBSCRIBE' button on the right side. The user navigates to their profile, which belongs to Timothy Adjokatse, a web developer and digital marketer. The profile includes a cover photo with design and development icons, a profile picture, and a brief bio. The user then accesses the 'Profile settings' menu, revealing options such as 'Account status', 'Archive', 'View as', 'Activity log', 'Manage posts', 'Review posts and tags', 'View Privacy Shortcuts', and 'Search profile'. The profile link is displayed at the bottom of the menu. The video concludes with a view of the profile page, showing Timothy Adjokatse's bio, his role as Founder and CEO at AdoTech, and his educational background. The 'Add to Story' and 'Edit profile' buttons are visible, along with a 'SUBSCRIBED' button on the right side.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with one male speaker explaining how to copy a Facebook profile link. He says you need to click on your profile and the three dots to find the link, encouraging the listener to try the same procedure. He then prompts the listener to subscribe and wait for alerts.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a social media interface, showcasing a live stream by a user named Abena Manokame, who has 20,624 followers and is currently live. The interface includes options to create a room or listen to the stream, with a visible 'Create room' button and a 'Listen' button. Below the live stream, a post by a user named Nanki Teii, posted one hour ago, reads 'You get light?' with 611 comments and 455 likes. The interface also features tabs for 'Reels,' 'Room,' 'Group,' and 'Live,' with the 'Rooms' tab highlighted. A 'Subscribe' button with a bell icon appears, indicating the option to subscribe to the channel. The video then transitions to a dark blue background with the text 'THANKS FOR WATCHING' in white and teal, followed by a teal circle with a white thumbs-up icon, symbolizing a 'like' gesture. The text 'SHARE &' appears in teal, followed by a red YouTube subscribe button with the word 'SUBSCRIBE' in white, encouraging viewers to subscribe to the channel. The video concludes with this call-to-action, emphasizing viewer engagement and channel support.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker thanking the audience, promoting his upcoming video on Facebook page creation and monetization requirements, and saying goodbye. Then a short electronic dance music clip plays.
